Danes to Decide on Euro And Their Role in Europe Danes face a referendum that asks whether they wish to preserve the krone and their status or follow 12 other states of the 15-member European Union in abandoning their money for a shared currency, the euro.

Danes to Decide on Euro And Their Role in Europe Danes face a referendum that asks whether they wish to preserve the krone and their status or follow 12 other states of the 15-member European Union in abandoning their money for a shared currency, the euro.
Tough Choices for the Kremlin Russia is facing difficult choices as it tries to downsize and restructure its military and to make it better equipped and prepared for national defense needs.
Israel's Kosher Compromise Religious leaders of Israel have come to a compromise over shmita, the sabbatical year when the land of Israel is supposed to lie fallow.
President Clinton and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, held a final, impromptu meeting in New Tork, rounding out a week of talks.
Philippine Hostages Freed The last four Westerners were freed from the jungle by Muslim rebel kidnappers who seized 21 people from a resort more than four months ago.

Nicaraguan Land Dispute More than a decade after the Sandinistas lost power, thousands of Nicaraguans and others are grappling with the legacy of their revolution: confiscated land, homes and businesses that were distributed to peasants and party loyalists alike.

Truckers End Blockades French truckers began lifting nationwide blockades at oil refineries and fuel depots after union leaders unanimously called for an end to a six-day protest that has strangled fuel supplies, causing airport delays and chaos at gas stations.
(AP)
NATIONAL

Pennsylvania Looms Large In the Presidential Race Pennsylvania is one of a handful of states where experts say the presidential race of 2000 will be decided. So the state is under something of a siege. Gov. George W. Bush has been to the state 14 times, and Vice President Al Gore had made no fewer than 17 campaign visits.

When Vice President Al Gore incorporated ''working families'' into his rhetoric, he pointed a finger at a central fact of American life: most of the nation's 72 million families feel they cannot make ends meet.
Democrats in Minnesota hope to unseat Senator Rod Grams, but the party's challengers have been using up their resources battling each other in a primary race.

Spending Increase Predicted Congress is poised to approve large increases in spending by federal agencies, pushing the national budget to record levels. Top Republicans predict a federal budget for the 2001 fiscal year that allocates at least $614 billion for discretionary spending, exceeding a ceiling set in April.
Violence in Entertainment The government plans to release a report that harshly criticizes the film, recording and video game industries for marketing violent entertainment to young people.
Philadelphia Faces Showdown Philadelphia's public schools have reopened, but the teacher's union is still fighting contract concessions and has authorized a strike.
Clinton Calls for Fire Aid President Clinton says he will seek to more than double federal spending on wildfire programs in the year ahead.
NEW YORK/REGION

An Aging Generation of Priests Finds Successors Conservative The Catholic priests who came of age during the Second Vatican Council interpreted the gospels as a spur to social action, fought for integration and school decentralization, built housing for the poor and spoke out on issues like nuclear disarmament and the Vietnam War. But as they prepare for retirement, they fear that their social values have by and large been abandoned by many newer, more conservative, priests.

Strike Over at the Modern The union representing 250 striking workers at the Museum of Modern Art voted to end its 134-day walkout just hours after reaching an agreement in which both sides made important concessions. The museum's workers applauded the contract.

Looking to a Senate Race Past Robert F. Kennedy Jr. --recruited by Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign to speak about the environment -- began reminiscing about his father's success in overcoming the accusations of carpetbagging.
